section.title: GDBM - The GNU database manager
section.para: This is an interface to the &gdbm;, which extends the standard &unix; ndbm.h.
section.simpara: When this module is present, &features-my; contains the symbol :GDBM.

listitem.para:
Open &filename-r; database file. The return value is a GDBM structure. :READ-WRITE can have one of following values: &reader-k;&writer-k; :WRCREAT :NEWDB
and :OPTION is one of
:SYNC :NOLOCK :FAST
If &filename-r; is actually an existing GDBM structure, then it is re-opened (if it has been closed), and returned as is.
The return value is &finalize;d with GDBM-CLOSE.
Return the default data conversion types.

listitem.simpara: Check whether &db-r; has been already closed.

warning.simpara: Only the above functions accept closed databases, the following functions &sig-err; when passed a closed database.

listitem.para: &db-r; is the GDBM structure returned by GDBM-OPEN. &key-r; is the key datum. &cont-r; is the data to be associated with the key. :FLAG can have one of following values: :INSERT :REPLACE

listitem.simpara: Search the database. The &type-k; argument specifies the return type.
Return the key of the first entry, as &type-k;. If the database has no entries, the return value is &nil;.
Return the key that follows &key-r;, as &type-k;, or &nil; if there are no further entries.
Syncronize the in-memory state of the database to the disk file.

listitem.para:
Set options on an already open database. &option-r; is one of following:
:CACHESIZE set the size of the internal bucket cache. (default is 100) :FASTMODE &t; or &nil; (obsolete)
:SYNCMODE &t; or &nil; :CENTFREE &t; or &nil; :COALESCEBLKS &t; or &nil; :DEFAULT-VALUE-TYPE :DEFAULT-KEY-TYPE see GDBM-OPEN

listitem.simpara: Return the underlying file size using lseek.

Iterate over the database keys, &options-r; are passed to GDBM-FIRSTKEY and GDBM-NEXTKEY. &body-r; is passed to &loop;, so you can use all the standard loop contructs, e.g., (do-db (k db) :collect (list k (gdbm-fetch k))) will convert the database to an &alist;.
Open the &filename-r;, execute the &body-r;, close the database.
